title: How does proton-proton fusion not violate the law of conservation of mass? - Quora

response.answer_text: It does, which is why it is such a rare event. Tunneling is required. RE: “How does proton-proton fusion not violate the law of conservation of mass?” Even in the core of the Sun, a proton will persist for over a billion years before it happens to be close enough to another proton as one of them reverse decays to a neutron and a positron, allowing the formation of a deuterium nucleus. This is the only source of neutrons in the core of the Sun Even inside nuclei, I think that two protons always have a neutron between them. proton-proton fusion does not yield He2.
